title: Kenya: Senate Blames KQ Managers for Huge Loss
text:
Nigeria: FG Grants 12 New Auto Assembly Plants Licences 
The CSs are expected at the committee on Thursday this week because the MPs have listed the matter as urgent. 
?The chairman, Starehe MP Maina Kamanda, said the committee had decided to summon the CSs because KQ is partly owned by the government, a 29 per cent share. 
Kamanda summoned the CSs after acting Transport Principal Secretary John Mosonik failed to provide a preliminary statement on the status of KQ's troubles yesterday. 
Instead, the PS asked for more time to contact the Treasury on the actual status of the company before giving an official statement. 
"If I give you my preliminary view, it may be inaccurate. I would need to contact Treasury on this. It is an issue that falls both under our ministry and Treasury and it would only be fair that we respond to an issue where we have gathered enough details," Mosonik told the committee. 
The PS said they would also wish to get more information from Kenya Airways management on its future plans. 
The committee issued the summons to the officials even as a Senate select committee already probing the airline blamed the management for the woes that face KQ. 
Kisumu Senator Anyang' Nyong'o, who chairs the committee, said poor investment decisions by the management and the high cost of its tickets had driven away passengers and eaten into the airline's revenue, skyrocketing KQ's indebtedness. 
The national carrier last week reported a net loss of Sh25.7billion in the financial year ending March 15, 2015. 
Nyong'o said the preliminary findings of the select committee had established the airline's liquidity was severely affected by the decision by management to hedge on fuel under arrangements that are not profitable for the company. 
Established in May, the committee has held several meetings, including two public hearings, but Nyong'o says the work is not yet complete. 
"The prima facie evidence so far gathered shows that the airline faces major problems which the committee is looking deeply into with management as well as other stakeholders," Nyong'o said. 
He summarised the challenges as expensive ticketing, which is non-competitive in the market and led to loss of passengers as well as revenue. 
Routing arrangements and partnerships also account for massive losses of revenue, particularly for lack of expansion of KQ flights on African routes. Kenya
